content.title: Right To Information Fellowship
content.details: The Right To Information Fellowship aims to promote research and innovative approaches to enhance the functioning of the RTI regime in India.
benefits: Opportunity to conduct research on RTI-related issues
Access to government resources and support
Publication of research output by the Government of India
eligibility: Only Indian nationals are eligible to apply
Individuals working under Central/State Government or Public Sector Undertakings can apply through proper channel
content.application_process: Applications must be submitted through the proper channel, with an advance copy sent along with required enclosures.

faqs.question: Will short-listed candidates be required to attend an interview or presentation?
faqs.answer: Yes, short-listed candidates may be called for an interview or presentation in Delhi as part of the final selection process.

faqs.question: What happens if an application is incomplete?
faqs.answer: Incomplete applications are liable to be rejected, so it is important to ensure that all the required information and documents are included.

faqs.question: Will any form of canvassing affect the selection process?
faqs.answer: Yes, canvassing in any form will lead to disqualification from the selection process.

faqs.question: What should the research proposal indicate?
faqs.answer: The research proposal should clearly indicate the deliverable or output that will be produced at the end of the fellowship.

faqs.question: Who will own the copyright of the research output?
faqs.answer: The copyright of the research output will vest in the Government of India.

faqs.question: Can fellows propose innovative approaches or methodologies for their research?
faqs.answer: Yes, fellows are encouraged to propose innovative approaches or methodologies that can add value to their research.

faqs.question: What happens if a fellow is unable to deliver the proposed research output?
faqs.answer: Fellows are expected to fulfill their commitment and deliver the proposed research output, but should communicate with authorities in exceptional circumstances.
